questions.question: A 9-year-old Golden Retriever presents with peripheral lymphadenopathy. Fine-needle aspirate reveals large, immature lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Lymphoma is the most common hematopoietic tumor in dogs and typically presents with peripheral lymphadenopathy. Cytology showing large, immature lymphocytes is diagnostic.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common malignant skin tumor in cats?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant skin tumor in cats, often associated with sun exposure and white-haired skin.

questions.question: A 7-year-old Boxer presents with a rapidly growing, ulcerated mass on the hindlimb. Cytology reveals round cells with purple granules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Mast cell tumors are common in Boxers and often present as rapidly growing, ulcerated masses. Cytology showing round cells with purple granules (mast cell granules) is diagnostic.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common primary bone tumor in dogs?
questions.explanation: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone tumor in dogs, typically affecting large breeds and occurring in the metaphysis of long bones.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for localized mast cell tumors in dogs?
questions.explanation: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for localized mast cell tumors. Adjuvant therapy may be considered for high-grade tumors.
